concall_summary:
## Earnings Call Analysis: DELHIVERY LTD (Q4+FY25)

### 1. Financial Highlights

#### Revenue Performance
- **Q4 FY25:** Revenue of Rs. 2,592 crores, up 6% YoY and down 8% QoQ.
- **FY25:** Revenue of Rs. 8,932 crores, total income at Rs. 9,372 crores, up nearly 10% YoY.
- **FY24:** Revenue grew from Rs. 7,320 crores in FY23 to nearly Rs. 9,000 crores in FY25.

#### Profitability
- **Q4 FY25:** EBITDA of Rs. 179 crores, 5.4% EBITDA margin (320 bps expansion YoY, 100 bps expansion QoQ).
- **Q4 FY25:** PAT of Rs. 37 crores, PAT margin (swing of Rs. 140 crores YoY, tripled from Q3).
- **FY25:** EBITDA of Rs. 570 crores, 6.4% EBITDA margin (expansion of nearly Rs. 250 crores, margin expansion of 260 bps YoY).
- **FY24 PAT:** Of Rs. 362 crores, 17% margin (vs. a loss of Rs. 249 crores in FY23).
- **FY23 to FY25 PAT:** Increased by Rs. 1,170 crores.

### 2. Segment Performance

#### Express Parcel
- **Q4 FY25:** Revenue of Rs. 1,256 crores.
- **Q4 FY25:** 177 million packages delivered, broadly flat YoY.
- **FY25:** Revenue of Rs. 5,320 crores, growth of about Rs. 300 crores YoY and about Rs. 800 crores compared to FY23.
- **FY25:** 750 million parcels delivered, broadly flat YoY.
- **FY25 Service EBITDA margin:** 16.2% (vs 18.4% in FY24).

#### Part Truckload (PTL)
- **Q4 FY25:** Revenue of Rs. 517 crores, 24% growth YoY and 12% growth QoQ.
- **Q4 FY25:** 460,000 tons of freight, 19% growth YoY and 11% growth QoQ.
- **FY25:** Revenue of Rs. 1,688 crores, 25% growth YoY.
- **FY25:** 1.8 million tons of freight, YoY growth of about 20%.
- **FY25 Service EBITDA margin:** 6.5% swing YoY.
- **Q4 FY25 Service EBITDA margin:** 10.8%.

#### Supply Chain Services
- **Q4 FY25:** Revenue of Rs. 230 crores, largely flat.
- **FY25:** Revenue growth of 17%.
- **FY25 Service EBITDA margin:** 2.2%.

#### Truckload
- **Q4 FY25:** Revenue remained flatish at Rs. 151 crores.
- **Q4 FY25:** Revenue at Rs. 626 crores vs Rs. 669 crores in the previous fiscal.

#### Cross Border Services
- **Q4 FY25:** Revenue remained largely flatish.
- **FY25:** Revenue at Rs. 179 crores vs Rs. 153 crores in the previous financial year.

### 3. Management Commentary
- **Sahil Barua, MD & CEO:** "A very satisfying quarter...This is the highest profitability that the company has declared."
- **Sahil Barua:** Anticipates PTL margins will be similar to Express Parcel business.
- **Sahil Barua:** "Delhivery has always been more than 100% of the profit pool of this industry."

### 4. Future Guidance
- Capex intensity will continue to remain largely stable and slowly taper towards long-term targets of 3.5% to 4%.
- Anticipates margins will expand in FY26 and beyond.
- Expects that in FY27 they will be able to start hitting their long-term Capex targets.

### 5. Strategic Initiatives
- Proposed acquisition of Ecom Express is under discussion with the Competition Commission of India.
- Expanding Delhivery Direct (on-demand three-wheeler, two-wheeler service) to Delhi and Bombay.

### 6. Key Risks
- Headwinds in the industry overall.
- Industry consolidation due to players' losses.
- Pricing pressure.

### 7. Capital Allocation
- Delhivery has about Rs. 5,493 crores of cash and cash equivalents on the balance sheet.

### 8. Operational Metrics
- **PIN Code reach:** 18,833 as of Q4 FY25.
- **Customers:** 44,000 at the end of Q4 FY25 (33,000 last year).
- **Fleet Utilization:** Fleet utilization has improved quite significantly between Q3 and Q4.
- **Dark stores:** The dark stores are now clocking at about 350 to 400 orders per day.

### 9. Q&A Highlights
- **PTL Growth:** Seen as too nascent to believe that the growth runway in PTL will be significantly different from what has been seen so far.
- **Ecom Express Acquisition:** Anticipates retaining about 30% of the volumes with the core Ecom Express network.
- **Capex:** Expects minimal Capex on automation equipment over the next two to three years.
- **Pricing:** Historically, Delhivery has led pricing in this industry. Expects pricing pressure to reduce going forward.
- **Customer Mix:** Realizations have gone up, and margins have trended down a little bit. It is entirely down to parcel mix.
